title: Add test case for multi valued query params
Query string split fixes
body:
Fixes the splitting of a query string which looks like `a=b=c;d=e&f=g` into:

```
a: "b=c",
d: "e",
f: "g",
```

title: Add extra log information from HandlerError
body:
We had error information being logged in `TRACE` by the `Router`, but this adds an extra log entry at the `DEBUG` level when an application has returned a `HandlerError` which is responsible for generating the `Response`. This ensures that setting the log level to debug yields some useful debug information.

Before:

```
[2018-02-25 21:42:19.274389000][gotham::middleware::chain][TRACE]pipeline complete, invoking handler
[2018-02-25 21:42:19.280751000][gotham::router][TRACE][d49dcd4c-07fb-433d-a42d-a64137f9fe88] converting error into http response during finalization: handler failed to process request (Error { err: "missing field `display_name`" })
[2018-02-25 21:42:19.280804000][gotham::handler::error][TRACE][d49dcd4c-07fb-433d-a42d-a64137f9fe88] HandlerError generating HTTP response with status: 400 Bad Request
[2018-02-25 21:42:19.280890000][gotham::router][TRACE][d49dcd4c-07fb-433d-a42d-a64137f9fe88] handler complete
```

After:

```
[2018-02-25 21:45:45.021858000][gotham::middleware::chain][TRACE]pipeline complete, invoking handler
[2018-02-25 21:45:45.030600000][gotham::handler::error][TRACE] converting Error to HandlerError: missing field `display_name`
[2018-02-25 21:45:45.030673000][gotham::router][TRACE][edd9e639-01e1-416e-a3b8-12bc735fccca] converting error into http response during finalization: handler failed to process request (Error { err: "missing field `display_name`" })
[2018-02-25 21:45:45.030722000][gotham::handler::error][DEBUG][edd9e639-01e1-416e-a3b8-12bc735fccca] HandlerError generating 400 Bad Request response: missing field `display_name`
[2018-02-25 21:45:45.030804000][gotham::router][TRACE][edd9e639-01e1-416e-a3b8-12bc735fccca] handler complete
```

title: Visibility review
body:
Reduces the visibility of things that don't need to be part of our public API.

Fixes #15.

This deprecates the `Router::new` function, and adds `#[allow(deprecated)]` to some test code and some existing rustdoc examples that use it. I'll be doing a review of our rustdoc next, so I'll tackle it there when I revisit the examples.

This deprecation is an early step towards deprecating the entire `TreeBuilder` API from our public API (though obviously we'll still use it internally), with the ultimate goal being that **all** routing needs be served by the builder API.

title: Add Middleware and Pipelines introduction
body: Actual diff: https://github.com/gotham-rs/gotham/compare/further-examples-structure-refinements...add-middleware-introduction

title: Add the logo and cleanup main README
Further examples structure refinements
body:
Having gotten our some of our new examples up on GitHub it quickly become evident that the number of examples we envisage having would become unworkable.

This PR enhances the structure by breaking examples down into key areas of functionality. Ordering is provided for both the areas of functionality and examples within each specific area of functionality to assist those learning Gotham from scratch.

I've also applied a lot of formatting rules to the set of examples we have so that going forward all examples written by both the core team and provided by the community will be in unison, making it easier to follow for newcomers.

Some examples have also been refined to ensure they only show the absolute minimum of code to explain their core concept, we don't won't well intended, but extraneous code, taking away from the specific learning objective each example brings with it.

Thoughts, pitchforks and offers of free cake are all welcome on this PR, but overall I feel this general concept puts us on a sustainable, long term path that will assist folks in learning Gotham.

title: Refactor to move the middleware chain, pipeline chain and pipeline set code to their own modules
body:
I could never remember exactly where these were defined, which seemed like a hint that they weren't in the right place. This introduces three new modules for these concepts: `middleware::chain`, `pipeline::chain`, and `pipeline::set`.

No changes here, just relocation and fixing imports.

title: Allow route definition with different pipelines
body:
For certain routing tree structures, it's quite difficult to selectively apply pipelines by delegating subtrees.

This gives greater control over the pipelines used for certain routes, by allowing the pipeline chain to be changed without changing the current tree node being operated on.

title: Fix typos
body: Fix typos in examples: replace `recieve` by `receive`

title: Add basic request components example
body:
Addresses issue #104 
It prints the request components on the terminal.

title: Highlight middleware that is in development
body:
The gotham core team will at times be working on middleware that is not ready for usage by others. 

This change to the directory structure is intended to ensure this fact is clearly highlighted to others.

title: Help Gotham contributors identify rustfmt version
body:
Previously it was reasonably painful to figure out which version of `rustfmt` was throwing up a diff when being run on CI.

This is now clearly output in Travis logs.

title: Support Cookie Prefixes
body:
This is one possible implementation for #6 
This provides a helper to ensure the associated attributes are set when a cookie name is set with a prefix. This was generally inspired by the way Play framework does this.

If attributes are not set in line with the prefix, they are changed when the cookie is serialised. A warning is emitted - to disable the warning a user would either have to set the cookie attributes correctly or remove the prefix.

See cookie prefix spec: https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-west-cookie-prefixes-05

title: Execute `rustfmt` during Travis CI run
body: Lets make sure Gotham code is always nice to read and adheres to the agreed standards of the wider Rust community.

title: Fix inconsistent example logs
body: Minor change to match `examples/*/README.md` examples to code output.

title: Add Hello Header example
body:
Example setting custom headers.

Fixes https://github.com/gotham-rs/gotham/issues/117. I'm very new to Rust so please do point out if there are more idiomatic ways of doing this or if I need to extend the example further.

title: Switch to serde for path and query string extractors
body:
This reimplements our `PathExtractor` and `QueryStringExtractor` ideas as a serde `Deserializer`, so that we populate app-provided structs via a derived `Deserialize` implementation. Aside from a few things moving to different modules, the primary difference in how this is used is:

**Old:**

```rust
#[derive(PathExtractor, StateData, StaticResponseExtender)]
struct MyPathParams {
    id: u32,
}
```

**New:**

```rust
#[derive(Deserialize, StateData, StaticResponseExtender)]
struct MyPathParams {
    id: u32,
}
```

`PathExtractor` / `QueryStringExtractor` types are still applied to routes in exactly the same way:

```rust
build_simple_router(|route| {
    route.get("/:id")
        .with_path_extractor::<MyPathParams>()
        .to(my_handler);
})
```

The advantages of this approach are that apps can make use of **any** type which can be deserialized with serde, and we get all the extra features of serde for free (e.g. `#[serde(rename = "..")]`, `#[serde(deserialize_with = "..")]`).

I'd appreciate feedback from anyone and everyone who has time to review this. There's a fair bit of code here, but I've tried to go fairly heavy on the code comments and tests just to prove it works in enough base cases that serde can handle the edge cases for us.

title: Fix rustfmt issues in handler module
Refactor core creation out of serve & listen
body:
This change decouples the code that creates a `Core` and `Handle` from the code that uses it - the former is pulled out into new functions `start_code` and co, while the latter remains in `serve` and `listen`.

As discussed in #95, the intention is for `serve`, `listen` and other necessary parts of the code can then be made public, providing an interface by which a user can start a gotham server on a provided `Handle` instance.

title: Include `Allow` header with a 405 response (rewrite)
body:
This is a competing solution for #3 (the other solution being #100). This builds the `Allow` list on-demand, rather than prepopulating it in the tree.

The advantages of this approach:

* We're only creating data which represents reality (contrast with #100 which unnecessarily populated a list)
* This is _far_ more capable of handling weird behaviour that could be thrown at us by custom `RouteMatcher` implementations in the future. I can think of some crazy `RouteMatcher` implementations that would trip up the logic in #100.
* The `Allow` list in this case could be used for _other_ error codes if the need arose in future. A small refactor would also see it more widely available (perhaps even via `State`) if/when the need arises. I can't see a reason to do it today, so I haven't.

I'm going to attempt an optimisation to remove the `HashSet` (and therefore the memory allocation) from `RouteNonMatch`, but this is otherwise ready for review / consideration.

title: Basic router example enhancement
body: Requires #105 prior to merge.

body: As described in #96.

This was only providing trace output in the general case. 

For the error case the error returned has been slightly enhanced to sure information is not lost (The benefits of the parse return type should be considered at some point using String is not ideal).

Closes #79.

Basic Router example

An example of the Gotham Router showing usage of HTTP verbs such as Get and Post.

#97 should be considered before this PR.

body:
I'd like **put** this **patch** into Gotham that adds functionality and doesn't **delete** anything.

Oh yes, that just happened.

title: Fully qualify module names in macros expansion
body: Fixes #80

title: Rename os-specific modules to os-specific names
body: Fixes #81

title: Update Gotham to 0.2-dev
body:
In the future appening `-dev` to master will occur the first time we start to make additions towards a future release (for any crate).

Versions with `-dev` will not get published to crates.io.

Once a set of features for a release are complete, `-alpha` and `-beta` identifiers and publishing to crates.io will occur, eventually followed by the final release.

title: Address Hyper deprecations and provide access to Tokio Handle
body:
This refactors some Gotham internals to address deprecation warnings in the latest version of Hyper. As a part of this refactor I've addressed #78 by passing the Tokio `Handle` through into `State` too.

This was mostly written before #84 and then merged with `master`. I was pretty careful in addressing the merge conflicts, but I think it's worth mentioning so you can keep an eye out for anything that's out of place.

title: Add simple API for applications that only require a single pipeline
Add a new example, "Hello Router"
body: Builds on the Hello World example making use of a Router to distribute requests to the same Handler.

title: Upgrade to Diesel 1.0.0
body: Originally proposed by @ChristophWurst [here](https://github.com/gotham-rs/middleware-diesel/pull/8) but I have closed that and manually ported here following merge of #85.

title: Merge projects to single repository
body:
There ended up being three phases with this PR

1. Repository merges
Combines the following repositories into the core Gotham repository (these will subsequently be removed once 0.2 ships and marked archived once this PR lands):

* https://github.com/gotham-rs/borrow-bag
* https://github.com/gotham-rs/middleware-diesel
* https://github.com/gotham-rs/middleware-template
* https://github.com/gotham-rs/hello-world
* https://github.com/gotham-rs/policies

Deprecates the following repositories (these will subsequently be removed once 0.2 ships and marked archived once this PR lands):

* https://github.com/gotham-rs/example-app

2. Deprecating kitchen-sink 
The directory `examples/kitchen-sink` has been removed. Subsequent PR (so each example can be correctly scrutinised) will add back in a number of example crates that will allow developers building Gotham backed apps to succulently explore all the various components that Gotham offers without a singular, over whelming chunk of code

3. Cleaning up README/policies
The intent of these has been kept but there was a lot of extraneous wording that we just didn't need. In the case of the main Gotham README I have also added some best practice sub headings including listing alternate projects.

Closes #76.

title: Implement custom derive for NewMiddleware
body:
As raised in #74, it's often the case that the `NewMiddleware` implementation is just a piece of boilerplate. A lot of use cases for middleware can be implementing using a single struct which just uses `Clone` to implement `NewMiddleware`. This goes one step further and allows `NewMiddleware` to be derived too.

The derived `NewMiddleware` implementation requires that the type also implements `Clone`.

title: Proposal to remove lifetime from TestResponse
Add experimental Router builder API
Write ThreadId as debug log statement
body: To assist with diagnosing issues with concurrency, we can ensure the current thread is written as a debug log statement before the request is dispatched to a Handler. The value should be considered opaque and need not correspond to any system-designated identifier for the thread, but is sufficient for proving whether requests are served by the same, or different threads.

title: Add an example using Tokio Timer
body: This example came up on #gotham and seemed useful as another basic example we could point to when using futures.

title: Update hyper to 0.11.7
body:
This allows sharing of the tokio core handle by using [`hyper::server::Http::serve_addr_handle`](https://docs.rs/hyper/0.11.7/hyper/server/struct.Http.html#method.serve_addr_handle) to create the http
server.

Motivation: I'm currently trying to integrate [Sentry](https://github.com/SecurityInsanity/sentry-rs) as Gotham middleware to report errors/crashes. Since the library uses async Hyper, a handle reference is needed. However, with the previous version of Hyper, the handle was created together with the server. At that point the router had to be set up already and thus it was impossible to use the same tokio core. Fortunately, the Hyper lib seems to have added this feature of a shared core recently.

title: Update borrow-bag crate
body:
I've simplified the `BorrowBag` construction to idiomatic Rust code.

- [ ] Requires https://github.com/gotham-rs/borrow-bag/pull/8

Let me know what you think. This change seams not to break the public interface.

title: Update README to reflect move from IRC to Gitter
Add support for catching panics from futures
body:
Attempting to catch panics from arbitrary futures requires a few steps:

1. Wrap the future in an unwind-safe wrapper which poisons the future if a panic occurs, to prevent further calls to `poll()` after such a panic.
2. Use the `catch_unwind` combinator from the `futures` crate to trap any panics from the now-unwind-safe `Future`.
3. Map the panic result into a hyper `Response`.

Fixes #17

title: Catch synchronous panics in `NewHandlerService`
body:
This is part 1 of solving #17:

> A `catch_unwind` which handles a panic in a `Handler` and/or `Middleware` below, before the `Future` is returned

A few notes about this:

1. We've introduced `RefUnwindSafe` in quite a few places. The need for this originated from `NewHandler: RefUnwindSafe`, which has transitively required the trait bound elsewhere;
2. The `regex::Regex` type (which we use for segment constraints) [isn't unwind safe due to interior mutability](https://play.rust-lang.org/?gist=957e5ca4ed4a293241b3cddef314fcbb&version=stable). We work around this by:
    1. Reducing the surface area to only the `is_match` function, via our `ConstrainedSegmentRegex` wrapper; and
    2. Trapping a panic (which should be impossible) therein, and **aborting the process** to avoid leaving invalid state in the thread-local storage inside `Regex`.
3. This PR adds a `catch_unwind` to the `NewHandlerService` logic, which is intended to be a last resort effort to stop the application server falling over. Future work will hopefully see a more graceful panic-catching middleware which gives the `ResponseExtender` time to intervene before the `Response` is sent. There's no ability, nor any intention, to be able to customise the response which is sent at the `NewHandlerService` level.

title: Bump chrono version to 0.4.0
body:
Small update to make gotham compatible with the latest version of `chrono`.

Edit: After a quick search of your other repositories I noticed gotham-rs/example-app also uses the older 0.3.0 version. I wanted to open a pull request that repo as well, however that would cause a version mismatch with chrono for gotham 0.1.0. Is there an example-app that tracks gotham master?

title: Make session middleware respect existing cookies
body:
Previously we hard set the cookies header which was causing anything
before this middleware that needed to set a cookie to simply not have its
cookies appear in the response headers.

Fixes #56.

title: Implement Clone for NewSessionMiddleware
body: To aid applications that want to pin the same session middleware at multiple places in their hierarchy, we can make the `NewSessionMiddleware` implement `Clone`.

title: Bincode session serialization
body: Switch to bincode instead of msgpack session serialization.

title: Refactor TestServer API
Refine SessionCookieConfig implementation
body:
The previous implementation was not ideal when we came to implement
configurable path values, mostly in that it was complex to update an
option that had runtime data associated with it.

The new implementation simply sets values on the SessionCookieConfig
struct directly making updates easier and future extensions simpler.

External usage should not be impacted by this change as the
existing public API was able to be kept and in the case of
`anchor_to_path` extended.

title: Fix blank session cookie bug
body:
This looks like a refactor gone wrong in b0b39047, which was missed and got merged after the initial (pre-refactor) version had already been reviewed. The problem is that an empty `Vec` with a capacity is still seen as a 0-length slice, since none of the elements are initialized.

The RNG attempts (quite successfully) to fill the 0-length slice, and the session is established with a 0-length identifier.

Originally reported in https://github.com/gotham-rs/example-app/issues/5

title: Disallow warnings when building in CI
body: Turns out it's pretty easy to miss these, since they don't appear when rebuilding an unchanged project. Trapping them at the CI level ensures we don't miss them during review.

title: Implement regex matching for request path segments
body:
Adds anchored (^..$) regex matching to the request path segment handling
and drops the `unimplemented!()` macro in favor of a concrete
implementation.

This also adds an `OrderedRegex` newtype as the exist Regex didn't
implement the traits required for PartialEq, Eq, PartialOrd, and Ord.
See the following Github issues for reasons why Regex doesn't natively
implement this:
https://github.com/rust-lang/regex/issues/313
https://github.com/rust-lang/regex/issues/364

This (hopefully) addresses and closes #10.

Only concerns with this pull request are the uses of `unwrap` when constructing the regular expression. Not sure how we want to handle errors for that.

title: Refine Handler/Middleware API
State API refactor
Route matcher enhancements
body:
Allows multiple route matchers to be invoked when considering a single route.

Moved `MethodAndAcceptRouteMatcher` to `AcceptRouteMatcher` and reduced functionality as part of this work. Developers should use the new `AndRouteMatcher` with `MethodOnlyRequestMatcher` to restore previous functionality.

Created the `AnyRouteMatcher` for use with delegated Routers.

Closes #42

title: Address new warnings on unused `extern` statements
body: Closes #40.

title: Add Route matcher that considers Request Method and Accept header values
body:
A `RouteMatcher` that succeeds when the `Request` has been made with one
or more acceptable HTTP request methods and has indicated an `Accept`
header that includes 1 or more supported media types.

No `Accept` header or the value of `*/*` will also positvely match.

Closes #37.

title: Improve concurrency by removing CpuPool from NewHandlerService
body:
Since 032249ac we've been using a `CpuPool` in `NewHandlerService` for concurrency, however there are a couple of downsides to this:

* We're bound by the single-thread performance of `hyper`
* We've got `Send` and `Sync` trait bounds in a lot of places where they wouldn't be otherwise necessary

This change moves the concurrency to the top level, starting a Tokio reactor per thread (defaulting to one thread for each CPU), and removes unnecessary `Send` / `Sync` trait bounds. I'm seeing about a 25% performance boost from this approach, just based on some very unscientific benchmarking.

Concept is based on [this gist from Alex Crichton](https://gist.github.com/alexcrichton/7b97beda66d5e9b10321207cd69afbbc), but some refactoring was needed first to attempt to support Windows, and then to ultimately use a different code path when apparently unable to share the same server socket across threads in Windows.

title: Fix type param being added by derive helper
body:
Addresses a bug where gotham_derive `ty_params` helper was attempting to
add the an additional constraint to provided types, specifically
`PathExtractor`.

Helper now takes any aditional type constraint as an Option, for the
short term I can't see this being used within Gotham itself but it seemed
like a reasonable tradeoff to ensure we didn't completely remove the
logic associated with doing this.

title: Add Appveyor configuration
body:
Enabled CI for Windows, to ensure we retain compatibility there.

Also includes a sneaky fix for a couple of unused imports that snuck in with #30.

title: Fix support for Windows
body:
Our usage of unix sockets for `TestServer` was preventing compilation on Windows. Originally, unix sockets were introduced to avoid having magic URLs in use for integration testing, essentially getting an anonymous, full-duplex pipe.

Another alternative here would be named pipes, however using TCP means we're closer to the real production code for integration tests, and we can support all platforms from a single implementation.

After seeing #29 from @target-san, and @braunse's fork, I realised this was a higher priority than I initially thought.

title: Fix the blog URL
body: It looks like the [current blog URL](https://staging.gotham.rs/blog) is not working and is pointing to a staging environment — this should point to the [regular blog URL](https://gotham.rs/blog) instead.

title: Remove the CC0 license from the repository
body:
This was a left over artifact from an earlier iteration and no component
of Gotham is actually CC0 licensed.

title: update license in cargo toml
body: Changes information in cargo.toml according to information found in COPYRIGHT.md

title: Add Travis support
body:
You'll need to enable Travis for the repository. I'd recommend doing that *before* this PR gets merged, so we can check that the `.travis.yml` works (note: turn off the "build without .travis.yml" option so it doesn't try to use the default ruby build on master).

Fixes #1 

From that issue:

> If possible the two releases prior to the current stable Rust also.

Unfortunately that's rather hard to do without hard coding the versions 🙁 . Maybe in a future PR (or if you really want it I guess I could try with this PR).

Edit: now also fixes #4 with coveralls integration through travis-cargo. You'll need to use enable coveralls for the repository to activate that (through their website).
